javax.time.calendrical

Interface TemporalAccessor.Query<R>

  • Enclosing interface:
    TemporalAccessor

    public static interface TemporalAccessor.Query<R>
    Strategy for querying a temporal object.

    This interface allows different kinds of query to be modeled. Examples might be a query that checks if the date is the day before February 29th in a leap year, or calculates the number of days to your next birthday.

    Implementations should not normally be used directly. Instead, the TemporalAccessor.query(Query) method must be used: 

       dateTime = dateTime.query(query);

    See Adjusters for a standard set of adjusters, including finding the last day of the month.

    Implementation notes

    This interface must be implemented with care to ensure other classes operate correctly. All implementations that can be instantiated must be final, immutable and thread-safe.

    • Field Detail

      • ZONE_ID

        static final TemporalAccessor.Query<ZoneId> ZONE_ID
        A strict query for the ZoneId.

        This queries a TemporalAccessor for the zone. The zone is only returned if the temporal conceptually contains a ZoneId. It will not be returned if the temporal only conceptually has an ZoneOffset. Thus a ZonedDateTime will return the result of getZone(), but an OffsetDateTime will return null.

        In most cases, applications should use ZONE as this query is too strict.

      • CHRONO

        static final TemporalAccessor.Query<Chrono<?>> CHRONO
        A query for the Chrono.

        This queries a TemporalAccessor for the chronology. LocalTime returns null as it is valid for all chronologies.

      • TIME_PRECISION

        static final TemporalAccessor.Query<ChronoUnit> TIME_PRECISION
        A query for the minimum supported time unit.

        This queries a TemporalAccessor for the time precision. If the target TemporalAccessor represents a consistent or complete temporal, date-time or time then this must return the smallest precision actually supported. Note that fields such as NANO_OF_DAY and NANO_OF_SECOND are defined to always return ignoring the precision, thus this is the only way to find the accurate minimum supported unit.

        For example, were GregorianCalendar to implement TemporalAccessor it would return a precision of MILLIS, whereas LocalDateTime returns NANOS. LocalDate and ZoneOffset have no time precision and thus returns null.

      • ZONE

        static final TemporalAccessor.Query<ZoneId> ZONE
        A lenient query for the ZoneId, falling back to the ZoneOffset.

        This queries a TemporalAccessor for the zone. It first tries to obtain the zone, using ZONE_ID. If that is not found it tries to obtain the OFFSET.

        In most cases, applications should use this query rather than #ZONE_ID.

        This query examines the offset-seconds field and uses it to create a ZoneOffset.

      • OFFSET

        static final TemporalAccessor.Query<ZoneOffset> OFFSET
        A query for the ZoneOffset.

        This queries a TemporalAccessor for the offset.

        This query examines the offset-seconds field and uses it to create a ZoneOffset.

    • Method Detail

      • doQuery

        R doQuery(TemporalAccessor temporal)
        Implementation of the strategy to query the specified temporal object.

        This method is not intended to be called by application code directly. Instead, the TemporalAccessor.query(Query) method must be used: 

           dateTime = dateTime.query(query);
        Implementation notes
        The implementation queries the input temporal object to return the result. For example, an implementation might query the date and time, returning the astronomical Julian day as a BigDecimal.

        This interface can be used by calendar systems other than ISO. Implementations may choose to document compatibility with other calendar systems, or validate for it by querying the chronology from the input object.

        Parameters:
        temporal - the temporal object to query, not null
        Returns:
        the queried value, avoid returning null
        Throws:
        DateTimeException - if unable to query
        ArithmeticException - if numeric overflow occurs
